p: Blue tits Cyanistes caeruleus, great tits Parus major, and coal tits Periparus ater throughout Britain and Ireland make extensive use of garden bird‚Äêfeeders and are major prey items of sparrowhawks Accipiter nisus (Perrins, 1979). It is therefore reasonable to expect that all three species could be affected similarly by changes in climate, predation risk, and other factors such as supplementary feeding practices, which have been shown to affect the phenotypes of garden birds (Plummer, Bearhop, Leech, Chamberlain, & Blount, 2018). Because small bird species in temperate climates rely on temperature as a cue for regulating body mass (Newton, 1969), anthropogenic increases in the mean winter temperature are likely to lead to predictable decreases in mean winter body mass in small birds. However, these changes may be quite small and long term, and therefore not easy to observe without access to large datasets.
